Award.AwardTitle: MPWR II: Mentoring Partnerships for Women in RUME

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will help stimulate the growth of Partnerships for Women in RUME (Research in Undergraduate Mathematics Education) and foster a sustainable support system for women at all career stages in undergraduate mathematics education research. Stemming from the need articulated in national reports and research findings, the project will emphasize face-to-face mentoring and a partnership system that targets participation amongst women researchers within undergraduate mathematics education. The project will also function as a clearinghouse for opportunities for established women to mentor newcomers into the field, and to build partnerships among women researchers of undergraduate mathematics education at all career stages.

The project goals are to provide an environment for women in the undergraduate mathematics education research community to discuss issues specific to them, as well as facilitate mentorship and partnership opportunities among graduate students and faculty, both junior and senior, within the research community. Building on the success of MPWR I, the project will initiate the process with a seminar that will occur in conjunction with the annual RUME conference. The project will have seventy participants. Following the RUME conference, participants will submit requests for formalized mentoring and partnership networks composed of one senior faculty, two junior faculty, and three graduate students. The project aligns with the national effort to support the careers of women and minorities within the STEM disciplines. It takes up specific recommendations for this support in the form of fostering personal, face-to-face mentoring and partnership opportunities. By supporting women in undergraduate mathematics education, the project seeks to increase the number of graduate students pursuing undergraduate mathematics education research who will go onto academic positions, as well as to increase the productivity of female junior and senior faculty who already hold academic positions. The MPWR seminar will further expand the role of women pursuing research in undergraduate mathematics education within in the broader Discipline Based Education Research (DBER) community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the past two years, with the generous support of the NSF, we have successfully run a seminar for women in the Research in Undergraduate Mathematics Education (RUME), called the MPWR seminar, which stands for Mentoring and Partnerships for Women in RUME. In February of 2014, the first MPWR seminar took place in Denver, CO and involved 60 participants: 20 graduate students, 3 post docs, and 38 faculty. In February of 2015, the second MPWR seminar was held in Pittsburgh, PA and involved 64 participants: 23 graduate students, 6 post docs, and 35 faculty.

The purpose of MPWR 2015: Mentoring and Partnerships for Women in RUME II was to develop a sustainable support system for women at all career stages in undergraduate mathematics education research. Through MPWR 2014, we began the process of developing such a network. Through MPWR 2015, we focused on supporting these networks to thrive and sustain. We view this as one more necessary step in fostering a long-term support network within the RUME community that we will continue in future iterations of the seminar. The seminar included 3 panel discussions, focused meal conversation topics, a Fireside chat session, and the establishment of MPWRment groups.

Through MPWR 2014 we initiated conversations regarding the difficulties we, as female academics, may face within our academic careers. This led to very candid and personal conversations, and the response from participants showed that these were much needed conversations. For MPWR 2015, we wanted to complement these conversations about potential hardships with a shift towards models for success. The topics of the three MPWR 2015 panel discussions reflect this shift. The theme of the first panel discussion was relationships; the panelists focused on ways we might navigate the various relationships that arise in our careers (mentor, mentee, advisor, advisee, teacher, peer, student, senior faculty, committee chair, etc.). The second panel addressed individual success by discussing what success might mean to the individual speakers, different conceptions of success, and how they have accomplished it in their lives. We prompted the final panel to discuss collaborative success – what success might mean on a collective level, how this can be accomplished, and concrete ways to accomplish it (such as examples of existing collaborative support structures). The leaders of the MPWR 2015 seminar chose three women to lead each panel discussion and assigned each panel a specific theme – but all specifics were left up to the speakers. Participants remarked that this gave the speakers ownership of the ideas discussed and maintained an intimate environment.

In addition to the shift in discussion topics, for MPWR 2015 we added two new features: the MPWRment groups and Fireside chats. Feedback from the MPWR 2014 seminar indicated that participants wanted more structured networking groups, and so in MPWR 2015 we organized participants into MPWRment groups. The MPWRment groups consist of 4-6 women at similar career stages (i.e., graduate students, post-docs, junior faculty, senior faculty, other). The MPWRment groups met for one hour to introduce themselves to one another, select a “leader” to keep them organized throughout the year, and discuss what they hoped to gain from such a networking group. After the

MPWRment group time, we had an hour for either free time or Fireside chats, where participants could informally chat with panel speakers to follow up on ideas presented during the panels.

After the seminar, we sent an exit survey to participants of MPWR 2015 to gain an understanding of how the seminar succeeded and how it might improve.
